hero.title: Prediction Market Microstructure
hero.subtitle: 12 data-driven analyses of 72M+ Kalshi and 404M+ Polymarket trades revealing how markets price probability, where biases hide, and who actually makes money.

analyses.title: Dataset Overview
analyses.description: A bird's-eye view of the Kalshi prediction market: how much was traded, when, and how the platform grew from a niche exchange to handling billions of contracts per quarter.
analyses.what_it_shows: Monthly trade counts and contract volumes on Kalshi from mid-2021 through late 2025. The platform saw exponential growth, especially around major events like elections and economic data releases. The top chart shows raw trade frequency; the bottom shows total contracts — a proxy for dollar-denominated volume.
analyses.takeaways: Kalshi's growth has been explosive: from a handful of trades in 2021 to millions per month by 2025. Most "No" outcomes outnumber "Yes" ~3:1, which makes sense — many markets ask "Will X unlikely thing happen?" and the answer is usually no. The 7.3M resolved markets give us a massive sample for testing calibration and bias.

learn.title: What is a Prediction Market?
learn.body: A prediction market lets you buy and sell contracts that pay out based on real-world events. For example, "Will it rain in NYC tomorrow?" — you can buy a YES contract for 40 cents. If it rains, you get $1 back (60 cent profit). If not, you lose your 40 cents. The price (40 cents) is the market's estimate that there's a 40% chance of rain. When thousands of traders buy and sell, the price becomes a crowd-sourced probability estimate — often more accurate than polls or expert forecasts.

key_terms.definition: A tradeable bet that pays $1 if an event happens, $0 if it doesn't. The price is between $0.01 and $0.99.
When one person buys a contract and another sells it. Each trade records the price, size (number of contracts), and time.
A market that has ended. The outcome is known — either YES (event happened) or NO (it didn't). This is how we check if prices were accurate.
Total number of contracts traded. More volume = more people participating = more reliable prices.

analyses.title: Calibration Curve
analyses.description: The most fundamental test in prediction markets: if a contract trades at 70 cents, does the event actually happen ~70% of the time? Perfect calibration means all points land on the diagonal.
analyses.what_it_shows: Each dot represents a price level (1–99 cents). The x-axis is the contract price (implied probability), the y-axis is how often contracts at that price actually won. The dashed gold line is perfect calibration. Points above it mean the market was underpricing the event; points below mean it was overpricing.
analyses.takeaways: Overall, Kalshi markets are remarkably well-calibrated in the 20–80 cent range — prices genuinely reflect probabilities. But at the extremes (especially 1–10 cents), points fall below the diagonal: cheap contracts win even less than their price implies. This is the "longshot bias" we dig into next.

learn.title: What is Calibration?
learn.body: Imagine a weather app that says "70% chance of rain" every day. If you check 100 such days, rain should have fallen on roughly 70 of them. If it only rained 50 times, the app is overconfident — it's poorly calibrated. Prediction markets work the same way. A contract priced at 70 cents claims there's a 70% chance the event happens. Calibration checks whether reality matches that claim. A perfectly calibrated market would have all points fall exactly on a 45-degree diagonal line. Deviations from that line reveal systematic errors we can study — and potentially exploit.

key_terms.definition: The contract price interpreted as a probability. A contract at 70 cents implies 70%. It's what the crowd "thinks" the probability is.
How often contracts at a given price actually resolved YES. This is the ground truth we compare against.
When a contract's price is higher than its actual win rate. Buyers of overpriced contracts lose money on average.
When a contract's price is lower than its actual win rate. Buyers of underpriced contracts profit on average.

analyses.title: Longshot Bias
analyses.description: One of the most famous findings in prediction markets: contracts priced at 1–5 cents consistently win far less than their price implies. People overpay for unlikely outcomes — the same psychology behind lottery tickets.
analyses.what_it_shows: Left chart: Implied probability (the price) vs actual win rate for contracts priced 1–20 cents. The blue bars are what the price claims the probability is; the orange bars are what actually happened. The gap = overpricing. Right chart: Expected return per $1 bet. Below the dashed $1.00 line means you're losing money on average.
analyses.takeaways: A 1-cent contract implies a 1% chance, but historically resolves "Yes" far less than 1% of the time. Betting on longshots in prediction markets can have worse expected returns than slot machines. This is structural — driven by retail traders who love cheap "lottery ticket" bets.

learn.title: Why Do People Overpay for Longshots?
learn.body: This is one of the most studied phenomena in behavioral economics. When something costs only 2 cents and could pay $1, people think "I could 50x my money!" The potential payoff feels exciting, and the cost feels negligible. But the math doesn't work: if a 2-cent contract only wins 0.5% of the time (instead of the 2% the price implies), your expected return is actually -75%. This is the same psychology that makes people buy lottery tickets with negative expected value. In prediction markets, this bias is called the 'favorite-longshot bias' — favorites (high-priced contracts) are underbet, while longshots (cheap contracts) are overbet.

key_terms.definition: A contract priced very low (1–10 cents), implying the event is unlikely. Think of it like a horse with 50:1 odds.
The average outcome if you made the same bet thousands of times. EV = (win probability × payout) − cost. Negative EV = losing bet.
A well-documented pattern: people underbet favorites and overbet longshots. Found in horse racing, sports betting, and now prediction markets.

insights.text: Longshots are worse than slot machines

analyses.title: Maker vs Taker Returns
analyses.description: Every trade has two sides: the maker (passive limit order) and the taker (aggressive market order). This analysis quantifies the systematic wealth transfer from takers to makers.
analyses.what_it_shows: Top: Excess return (actual win rate minus implied probability) for takers (red) and makers (green) at each price level. Takers are negative almost everywhere — they overpay. Makers earn small positive excess returns consistently. Bottom: Aggregate P&L by price bucket. The total wealth transfer is massive: takers have lost 143 million contracts to makers.
analyses.takeaways: The "institutional edge" in prediction markets isn't superior forecasting. It's being a liquidity provider — patient, passive, and collecting the spread. This mirrors traditional finance where market makers profit from structure, not alpha.

learn.title: Makers vs Takers: The Hidden Game
learn.body: Think of a farmer's market. A maker is like a vendor who puts up a sign saying "Tomatoes: $3/lb." They set the price and wait. A taker is the person who walks up and says "I'll buy at $3." The maker provides liquidity (makes goods available); the taker consumes it. In prediction markets, makers place limit orders at specific prices and wait. Takers hit those orders with market orders. Makers earn a small edge on each trade because they get to set favorable prices. Over millions of trades, these tiny edges compound into massive profits — $144M in this dataset. This is why almost all professional trading firms are makers, not takers.

key_terms.definition: A trader who places an order at a specific price and waits for someone to match it. They 'make' the market by providing liquidity.
A trader who accepts an existing price. They want to trade NOW and pay a premium for immediacy.
How much better (or worse) a trade performed versus what the price implied. Positive = outperformed, negative = underperformed.
The gap between the best buy price and best sell price. Makers live inside this spread, earning small profits on each trade.

analyses.title: Trade Size Distribution
analyses.description: Exploring how trade sizes are distributed — most trades are small (retail), but a tiny fraction of large trades drives most of the volume.
analyses.what_it_shows: Left: Log-log histogram of trade sizes. The distribution is heavily right-skewed — most trades are 10–100 contracts, but some are 10,000+. Right: A Lorenz curve showing volume concentration. The bottom 97.6% of trades (by size) account for only half the total volume.
analyses.takeaways: The mean is 6x the median, signaling a fat-tailed distribution. A small number of large traders dominate volume, consistent with institutional/whale participation alongside a broad retail base.

learn.title: Why Trade Size Matters
learn.body: If you walk into a casino and see everyone betting $5 on roulette, that's a retail-dominated market. But if one person walks in and puts $50,000 on the table, they move the game. Prediction markets work the same way. Most participants trade small amounts (10–100 contracts), but a handful of large players (whales) dominate the total volume. This matters because large trades typically come from more informed or sophisticated participants. When you see a fat-tailed distribution (long right tail), it means extreme events (huge trades) happen far more often than a normal distribution would predict. Understanding who you're trading against is critical — if whales are on the other side, you might be the 'dumb money.'

key_terms.definition: A statistical pattern where extreme values occur much more often than expected. The 'tail' of the distribution is thick, not thin.
A graph showing inequality of distribution. If perfectly equal, it's a straight diagonal. The more it bows, the more concentrated the volume.
A trader who places unusually large orders. In crypto and prediction markets, whale activity can move prices significantly.
When the mean is much larger than the median, it means a few extreme values are pulling the average up. Here: median = 40, mean = 253.

analyses.title: Returns by Hour of Day
analyses.description: Does the time you trade matter? This analysis checks whether taker excess returns vary by hour, revealing when informed vs uninformed participants are most active.
analyses.what_it_shows: Each bar shows the taker's average excess return (actual win rate minus implied probability) for trades placed during that UTC hour. Green bars = positive excess return (takers did better than implied), red bars = negative. The gray background indicates volume.
analyses.takeaways: Returns aren't uniform across the day. Certain hours show more negative taker returns — likely when more uninformed/retail flow hits the market. Periods with slightly positive taker returns may correspond to when informed traders are active and picking off stale quotes.

learn.title: Time-of-Day Effects in Trading
learn.body: Not all hours are created equal. In traditional stock markets, the first and last hours of trading see the most volume and the most price movement. The same patterns exist in prediction markets. When retail traders are most active (evenings, after work), there tends to be more 'uninformed flow' — trades that aren't based on superior information. This is when makers profit most, because they're trading against people who are trading for entertainment or on gut feel. Conversely, during hours when informed traders are active (when news breaks, around data releases), prices are more accurate and takers may actually have an edge. Understanding these patterns can help you decide WHEN to trade, not just WHAT.

key_terms.definition: Trades placed by people who have better information or analysis than the current market price reflects.
Trades placed for entertainment, gut feel, or without a specific informational advantage. This is what most retail traders generate.
A limit order at a price that no longer reflects current information. Informed traders 'pick off' stale quotes for profit.

insights.text: Returns vary by time of day
Informed flow clusters at certain hours

analyses.title: Calibration Surface
analyses.description: Going beyond the 1D calibration curve: a 2D heatmap showing how mispricing varies by both price level and time-to-close. This is the kind of analysis hedge funds use to build time-varying entry/exit rules.
analyses.what_it_shows: Each cell shows the mispricing (actual win rate minus implied probability, in percentage points) for a specific price bucket and time-to-close bucket. Green = market underpriced the event. Red = market overpriced it.
analyses.takeaways: Mispricing isn't static — it changes as resolution approaches. Some price/time combinations show consistent biases that could be exploited with time-aware strategies. This is more informative than a single calibration curve because it reveals when biases are strongest.

learn.title: From 1D to 2D: Why Time Matters
learn.body: The calibration curve (Analysis 2) told us whether prices match reality at each price level. But it ignores a crucial variable: time. A contract trading at 50 cents might be perfectly calibrated 30 days before resolution, but systematically wrong 1 hour before. This surface adds the time dimension. Think of it like weather forecasting: a 7-day forecast for 70% rain is less reliable than a 1-hour forecast for 70% rain. Markets work similarly — prices near resolution should be more accurate. When they're NOT, that's a tradeable signal. Hedge funds build algorithms that look for exactly these 2D patterns: specific price ranges at specific times-to-close where the market consistently gets it wrong.

key_terms.definition: How much time remains before a market resolves (ends). Also called 'time to expiry' or 'time to maturity' in traditional finance.
The gap between what the market price implies and what actually happened. Positive = underpriced (buy opportunity). Negative = overpriced (sell opportunity).
A systematic, repeatable pattern that can be used to make trading decisions. Not every pattern is a signal — it must persist over time and many observations.

analyses.title: Monte Carlo Kelly Sizing
analyses.description: Standard Kelly criterion over-sizes because it treats your estimated edge as certain. This analysis uses Monte Carlo resampling on real longshot trades to show the distribution of possible outcomes and drawdowns.
analyses.what_it_shows: Top-left: Distribution of max drawdowns across 5,000 simulated trading paths. Top-right: Distribution of final returns — green = profitable paths, red = losing paths. Bottom-left: 50 sample equity curves showing the range of possible outcomes. Bottom-right: Kelly fraction sensitivity — how returns change as you bet larger fractions.
analyses.takeaways: The longshot YES signal has negative edge (-1.96 percentage points) — confirming longshot bias. Even with "optimal" Kelly sizing, most simulated paths lose money. This demonstrates why naive longshot betting is unprofitable and why Monte Carlo is essential for understanding the range of outcomes.

learn.title: Kelly Criterion: How Much Should You Bet?
learn.body: Even if you find a genuine edge (a bet with positive expected value), you can still go broke by betting too much. The Kelly criterion is a famous mathematical formula that tells you the optimal fraction of your bankroll to bet on each opportunity. Bet more than Kelly and you risk ruin. Bet less and you leave profit on the table. But here's the catch: Kelly assumes you know your exact edge. In practice, you're estimating it from data — and estimates have uncertainty. This is where Monte Carlo simulation comes in. Instead of calculating one answer, we run 5,000 simulated trading histories, each randomly sampling from real trades. This gives us a DISTRIBUTION of outcomes — showing not just the average, but the worst-case drawdowns, the probability of going broke, and how sensitive results are to bet sizing. It's the difference between "this bet averages +5%" and "this bet averages +5% but has a 30% chance of losing half your bankroll."

key_terms.definition: A formula for optimal bet sizing: f* = (edge / odds). It maximizes long-run growth rate while avoiding ruin. Named after John Larry Kelly Jr. (1956).
Running thousands of random scenarios to understand the range of possible outcomes. Instead of one prediction, you get a probability distribution.
The largest peak-to-trough decline in your bankroll during a trading period. A 50% drawdown means your account fell by half at some point.
The chance of losing your entire bankroll. Even with positive expected value, aggressive bet sizing can lead to ruin through bad luck sequences.

analyses.title: Kalshi vs Polymarket
analyses.description: A side-by-side comparison of the two largest prediction market platforms: Kalshi (regulated US exchange) and Polymarket (crypto-native, on-chain). We compare monthly trade growth, cumulative scale, and market diversity.
analyses.what_it_shows: Polymarket dwarfs Kalshi in raw trade volume — 404M vs 72M trades — driven by crypto-native users and on-chain accessibility. Polymarket saw explosive growth during the 2024 US election cycle. Kalshi has far more individual markets (7.7M vs 409K) reflecting its more granular event structure (e.g. individual game props).
analyses.takeaways: Both platforms are growing fast, but they serve different audiences. Polymarket dominates in volume per market while Kalshi provides market breadth. Their growth curves show prediction markets entering mainstream adoption.

learn.title: Prediction Market Platforms
learn.body: Prediction markets let you trade contracts that pay out based on real-world events. Kalshi is a CFTC-regulated US exchange using an order book model with cents-denominated contracts. Polymarket is a crypto-native platform on Polygon where trades settle on-chain using USDC. The two represent fundamentally different approaches: regulatory compliance vs decentralized accessibility.

key_terms.definition: A CFTC-regulated prediction market exchange based in the US. Users trade binary and ranged contracts on events like elections, weather, economics, and sports.
A decentralized prediction market built on the Polygon blockchain. Trades settle in USDC (a stablecoin) with smart contract-based resolution.
Refers to transactions recorded directly on a blockchain. Polymarket trades are on-chain, meaning every trade is publicly verifiable on the Polygon network.
A list of buy and sell orders at different prices. Both platforms use order book models, but Polymarket also used an earlier AMM (automated market maker) system.

analyses.title: Whale Tracker
analyses.description: Analyzing 1.93 million unique Polymarket trading addresses to reveal the extreme concentration of volume among a handful of 'whale' traders. On-chain data means we can see every address's total activity.
analyses.what_it_shows: Polymarket trading is extraordinarily concentrated. The top 100 addresses (0.005% of traders) account for 63.2% of all volume. The top 1% controls 87% of volume. The Gini coefficient of 0.969 is one of the highest concentration levels seen in any financial market — meaning a tiny fraction of wallets dominates the entire platform.
analyses.takeaways: Prediction markets are dominated by whales. Most addresses trade rarely (800K+ made only 1 trade), while a few hundred accounts generate the majority of liquidity and volume. This has implications for price discovery — a few sophisticated actors likely set prices that millions of casual users follow.

learn.title: Whale Analysis & Concentration
learn.body: In crypto markets, a 'whale' is an address controlling outsized capital or volume. Since Polymarket is on-chain, every trade is publicly linked to a wallet address, enabling concentration analysis impossible on traditional exchanges. The Lorenz curve and Gini coefficient measure how unevenly volume is distributed — a Gini of 1.0 would mean one address does all the trading.

key_terms.definition: A number between 0 and 1 measuring inequality. 0 = perfectly equal (everyone trades the same amount), 1 = perfectly unequal (one address does everything). Polymarket's 0.969 indicates extreme concentration.

A graph showing cumulative share of volume vs share of addresses. A perfectly equal market would follow the diagonal. The further the curve bows away from the diagonal, the more concentrated trading is.
A trader with outsized market impact. In Polymarket, the top 100 addresses control over 63% of all volume, making them market-moving whales.
Because Polymarket runs on Polygon, every trade is publicly auditable. You can see exactly which address traded what, creating full transparency unlike traditional markets.

analyses.title: Market Categories
analyses.description: Breaking down Kalshi's 7.7 million markets into categories — Sports, Politics, Crypto, Economy, Weather, Entertainment, and more — to see what types of events attract the most trading activity.
analyses.what_it_shows: Sports dominate Kalshi with 3.9M markets and 7.5B contracts in volume, driven by granular single-game props (NFL, NBA, etc.). Politics punches far above its weight — only 6,881 markets but 1.6B volume, meaning political markets are individually massive. Crypto and Economy & Finance round out the top 5. The stacked area chart shows how sports markets exploded in 2024-2025.
analyses.takeaways: Kalshi's growth is heavily driven by sports betting — particularly NFL and NBA game props. Political markets are few in number but generate enormous volume per market. The 'Other' category is large, suggesting many niche markets that don't fit clean categories. Weather and Health markets remain small but represent Kalshi's unique regulatory positioning.

learn.title: Market Categories on Kalshi
learn.body: Kalshi structures markets as binary yes/no contracts on specific event outcomes. Each 'event' can have many individual markets — for example, a single NFL game might generate dozens of prop bets (player stats, point spreads, totals). This is why Sports has 3.9M markets. Political markets tend to be bigger events with fewer sub-markets but attract massive concentrated volume during election seasons.

key_terms.definition: Kalshi's internal identifier for groups of related markets. For example, KXMVENFLSINGLEGAME groups all prop bets for a specific NFL game.
A market with exactly two outcomes: Yes or No. The contract pays $1 if the event happens and $0 if it doesn't.
Total number of contracts traded in a market. Higher volume means more liquidity and typically tighter spreads.
A bet on a specific proposition within a larger event — e.g., 'Will Player X score 20+ points?' rather than just 'Who wins the game?'

analyses.title: Spread & Liquidity
analyses.description: Analyzing bid-ask spreads across 334K Kalshi markets to understand liquidity conditions — how spreads relate to volume, time-to-expiry, and where across the price spectrum liquidity is deepest.
analyses.what_it_shows: The average Kalshi spread is 58¢ (median 78¢) — extremely wide by traditional market standards, reflecting the nascent nature of prediction markets. Spreads narrow dramatically with volume (high-volume markets under 20¢). Time-to-close shows that markets far from expiry tend to have widest spreads. The 'liquidity smile' shows spreads are tightest at extreme prices (near 0 or 100¢) and widest in the 30-70¢ range where uncertainty is highest.
analyses.takeaways: Prediction market liquidity is still thin — most markets have wide spreads that make frequent trading expensive. The relationship between volume and spread suggests that popular markets (politics, major sports) are much more efficient than niche ones. If you're trading, stick to high-volume markets to minimize spread costs.

learn.title: Understanding Bid-Ask Spreads
learn.body: The bid-ask spread is the difference between the highest price a buyer will pay (bid) and the lowest price a seller will accept (ask). It represents the cost of immediately trading — you buy at the ask and sell at the bid, instantly losing the spread. Market makers profit from this spread by posting both bids and asks. In traditional stock markets, spreads are fractions of a penny. In prediction markets, they can be tens of cents, reflecting lower liquidity and higher risk.

key_terms.definition: The difference between the best bid (highest buy) and best ask (lowest sell) price. A 10¢ spread means you lose 10¢ per contract just from the cost of trading.
How easily you can trade without moving the price. High liquidity = tight spreads, lots of orders. Low liquidity = wide spreads, hard to trade large sizes.
The pattern where spreads are tightest at extreme prices (near 0¢ or 100¢) and widest in the middle (50¢). This mirrors the options volatility smile.
The midpoint between bid and ask: (bid + ask) / 2. Used as a fair value estimate when the spread is wide.

insights.text: Avg 58¢ spread: very wide by market standards
High-volume markets have much tighter spreads
Liquidity smile: edges are cheapest to trade
